text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Encounter DomainResourceAn interaction during which services are provided to the patient
identifier Σ0..*IdentifierIdentifier(s) by which this encounter is known
status ?! Σ1..1codeplanned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled
EncounterState (Required)
statusHistory 0..*ElementList of Encounter statuses
status 1..1codeplanned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled
EncounterState (Required)
period 1..1PeriodThe time that the episode was in the specified status
class Σ0..1codeinpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +
EncounterClass (Required)
type Σ0..*CodeableConceptSpecific type of encounter
EncounterType (Example)
patient Σ0..1PatientThe patient present at the encounter
episodeOfCare Σ0..1EpisodeOfCareAn episode of care that this encounter should be recorded against
incomingReferralRequest 0..*ReferralRequestIncoming Referral Request
participant Σ0..*ElementList of participants involved in the encounter
type Σ0..*CodeableConceptRole of participant in encounter
ParticipantType (Required)
period 0..1PeriodPeriod of time during the encounter participant was present
individual Σ0..1Practitioner | RelatedPersonPersons involved in the encounter other than the patient
fulfills Σ0..1AppointmentThe appointment that scheduled this encounter
period 0..1PeriodThe start and end time of the encounter
length 0..1DurationQuantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
reason Σ0..*CodeableConceptReason the encounter takes place (code)
EncounterReason (Example)
indication 0..*AnyReason the encounter takes place (resource)
priority 0..1CodeableConceptIndicates the urgency of the encounter
Priority (Example)
hospitalization 0..1ElementDetails about an admission to a clinic
preAdmissionIdentifier 0..1IdentifierPre-admission identifier
origin 0..1LocationThe location from which the patient came before admission
admitSource 0..1CodeableConceptFrom where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
AdmitSource (Required)
dietPreference 0..1CodeableConceptDiet preferences reported by the patient
PatientDiet (Example)
specialCourtesy 0..*CodeableConceptSpecial courtesies (VIP, board member)
Courtesies (Required)
specialArrangement 0..*CodeableConceptWheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc
Arrangements (Required)
destination 0..1LocationLocation to which the patient is discharged
dischargeDisposition 0..1CodeableConceptCategory or kind of location after discharge
DischargeDisp (Required)
dischargeDiagnosis 0..1AnyThe final diagnosis given a patient before release from the hospital after all testing, surgery, and workup are complete
reAdmission 0..1booleanIs this hospitalization a readmission?
location 0..*ElementList of locations the patient has been at
location 1..1LocationLocation the encounter takes place
status 0..1codeplanned | present | reserved
EncounterLocationStatus (Required)
period 0..1PeriodTime period during which the patient was present at the location
serviceProvider 0..1OrganizationThe custodian organization of this Encounter record
partOf 0..1EncounterAnother Encounter this encounter is part of

element.short: An interaction during which services are provided to the patient
element.definition: An interaction between a patient and healthcare provider(s) for the purpose of providing healthcare service(s) or assessing the health status of a patient.

element.short: Logical id of this artefact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
element.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

element.short: planned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled
element.definition: planned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled.

mapping.map: No clear equivalent in V2.x; active/finished could be inferred from PV1-44, PV1-45, PV2-24; inactive could be inferred from PV2-16

element.short: List of Encounter statuses
element.definition: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource. This status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without the needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.

element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: planned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled
element.definition: planned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled.

element.short: The time that the episode was in the specified status
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

element.short: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +
element.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

element.short: Specific type of encounter
element.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
element.comments: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

element.short: The patient present at the encounter
element.definition: The patient present at the encounter.
element.comments: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient may not actually be known in all contexts of use.

element.short: An episode of care that this encounter should be recorded against
element.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as govt reporting, or issue tracking.

element.short: Incoming Referral Request
element.definition: The referral request that this encounter is satisfies (incoming referral).

element.short: List of participants involved in the encounter
element.definition: The main practitioner responsible for providing the service.

element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Role of participant in encounter
element.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
element.comments: The Participant Type indicates how an individual parcitipates in an encounter. It includes non practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the Practitioner Roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

element.short: Period of time during the encounter participant was present
element.definition: The period of time that the specified participant was present during the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounters period.

element.short: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
element.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

element.short: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
element.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

mapping.map: SCH-1-placer appointment ID / SCH-2-filler appointment ID

element.short: The start and end time of the encounter
element.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
element.comments: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

element.short: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
element.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
element.comments: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

mapping.map: (PV1-45 less PV1-44) iff ( (PV1-44 not empty) and (PV1-45 not empty) ); units in minutes

element.short: Reason the encounter takes place (code)
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.

binding.name: EncounterReason
binding.description: Reason why the encounter takes place

mapping.map:
EVN-4-event reason code / PV2-3-admit reason (note: PV2-3 is nominally constrained to inpatient admissions; V2.x makes no vocabulary suggestions for PV2-3; would not expect PV2 segment or PV2-3 to be in use in all implementations
)

element.short: Reason the encounter takes place (resource)
element.definition:
Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis.
The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.

mapping.map: Resources that would commonly referenced at Encounter.indication would be Condition and/or Procedure. These most closely align with DG1/PRB and PR1 respectively.

element.short: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
element.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

binding.name: Priority
binding.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter

element.short: Details about an admission to a clinic
element.definition: Details about an admission to a clinic.

element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. element.short: Pre-admission identifier
element.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

element.short: The location from which the patient came before admission
element.definition: The location from which the patient came before admission.

element.short: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
element.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

binding.name: AdmitSource
binding.description: From where the patient was admitted

element.short: Diet preferences reported by the patient
element.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
element.requirements: Used to track patient's diet restrictions and/or preference. For a complete description of the nutrition needs of a patient during their stay, one should use the nutritionOrder resource which links to Encounter.

binding.name: PatientDiet
binding.description: Medical, cultural or ethical food preferences to help with catering requirements

element.short: Special courtesies (VIP, board member)
element.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

element.short: Wheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc
element.definition: Wheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc.

mapping.map: PV1-15-ambulatory status / OBR-30-transportation mode / OBR-43-planned patient transport comment

element.short: Location to which the patient is discharged
element.definition: Location to which the patient is discharged.

element.short: Category or kind of location after discharge
element.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

element.short: The final diagnosis given a patient before release from the hospital after all testing, surgery, and workup are complete
element.definition: The final diagnosis given a patient before release from the hospital after all testing, surgery, and workup are complete.

element.short: Is this hospitalization a readmission?
element.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission.

element.short: List of locations the patient has been at
element.definition: List of locations at which the patient has been.

element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. element.short: Location the encounter takes place
element.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

mapping.map: PV1-3-assigned patient location / PV1-6-prior patient location / PV1-11-temporary location / PV1-42-pending location / PV1-43-prior temporary location

element.short: planned | present | reserved
element.definition: The status of the participants presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.

element.short: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
element.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

element.short: The custodian organization of this Encounter record
element.definition: An organization that is in charge of maintaining the information of this Encounter (e.g., who maintains the report or the master service catalog item, etc.). This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different. This MAY not be not the Service Delivery Location's Organization.

mapping.map: PV1-10-hospital service / PL.6 Person Location Type & PL.1 Point of Care (note: V2.x definition is "the treatment or type of surgery that the patient is scheduled to receive"; seems slightly out of alignment with the concept name 'hospital service'. Would not trust that implementations apply this semantic by default)

element.short: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
element.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).

element.short: An interaction during which services are provided to the patient
element.definition: An interaction between a patient and healthcare provider(s) for the purpose of providing healthcare service(s) or assessing the health status of a patient.

element.short: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
element.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

element.definition: planned | arrived | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled.

mapping.map: No clear equivalent in V2.x; active/finished could be inferred from PV1-44, PV1-45, PV2-24; inactive could be inferred from PV2-16
